KH.content: acc. Hegel, Plato uses myth because he’s impotent, a ludico-mythological drift (dérive), Aristotle Hegel’s guarantor of seriousness
KH.linkedContent: acc. Hegel, Plato uses myth because he’s impotent, a ludico-mythological drift (dérive), Aristotle Hegel’s guarantor of seriousness

KH.content: Aristotle: “those who philosophize w/ recourse to myth are not worth treating seriously”
KH.linkedContent: Aristotle: “those who philosophize w/ recourse to myth are not worth treating seriously”

KH.content: Plato never qualified khōra as matter (hylè) like Aristotle did
KH.linkedContent: Plato never qualified khōra as matter (hylè) like Aristotle did

GT.content: mediating desire, measuring morality, mediocrity: who gives themselves the right of right measure? paradoxical hubris of measure [thoughtless to laugh at this position]
GT.linkedContent: mediating desire, measuring morality, mediocrity: who gives themselves the right of right measure? paradoxical hubris of measure [thoughtless to laugh at this position]

GT.content: Aristotle differentiates tukhē from automaton (chance from human finality), offers example of creditor going to market & getting his debt paid back: pas de don, everything happens en marchant
GT.linkedContent: Aristotle differentiates tukhē from automaton (chance from human finality), offers example of creditor going to market & getting his debt paid back: pas de don, everything happens en marchant

GT.content: for Aristotle, happy medium, good measure, megaloprepreia (liberality), giving to common good, better character than the cumin cutter, he who would shave an egg
GT.linkedContent: for Aristotle, happy medium, good measure, megaloprepreia (liberality), giving to common good, better character than the cumin cutter, he who would shave an egg

GT.content: chremastics vs. economy: 1) chremastics, ovular or seminal capital, “bad infinite” of money, no limit 2) economy, oikos, care for home, hearth, limited to necessary goods
GT.linkedContent: chremastics vs. economy: 1) chremastics, ovular or seminal capital, “bad infinite” of money, no limit 2) economy, oikos, care for home, hearth, limited to necessary goods

GT.content: limit gets blurred once there’s monetary sign, or simply sign, once there’s differance & credit, family no longer contained > this originary ruin is chance of hospitality—like counterfeit money, chance for gift itself [Aristotle looks for balanced limit, not Derrida]
GT.linkedContent: limit gets blurred once there’s monetary sign, or simply sign, once there’s differance & credit, family no longer contained > this originary ruin is chance of hospitality—like counterfeit money, chance for gift itself [Aristotle looks for balanced limit, not Derrida]

R.content: Aristotle’s Prime Mover, the first desirable, gives a life that exceeds the life of a human, continuous, unending—for us, impossible
R.linkedContent: Aristotle’s Prime Mover, the first desirable, gives a life that exceeds the life of a human, continuous, unending—for us, impossible

R.content: energeia of this pure activity is “pleasure (hēdonē), circle of taking pleasure in oneself (jouissance de soi); a specular auto-affection that accords w/ thinking of thought
R.linkedContent: energeia of this pure activity is “pleasure (hēdonē), circle of taking pleasure in oneself (jouissance de soi); a specular auto-affection that accords w/ thinking of thought

R.content: for Aristotle, the One [i.e. Prime Mover] is above multiplicity, we should not all be kings, Aristotle’s against polykoirania
R.linkedContent: for Aristotle, the One [i.e. Prime Mover] is above multiplicity, we should not all be kings, Aristotle’s against polykoirania

R.content: for Aristotle, democracy: equality according to number, not worth, which makes democracy a freedom founded on equality, as opposed to being governed and govern in turn
R.linkedContent: for Aristotle, democracy: equality according to number, not worth, which makes democracy a freedom founded on equality, as opposed to being governed and govern in turn

MONL.content: Aristotle’s model: the “most” this, the “best” that: paradigmatic example
MONL.linkedContent: Aristotle’s model: the “most” this, the “best” that: paradigmatic example

FK.content: prayer is neither true nor false
FK.linkedContent: prayer is neither true nor false

LOBL.content: [compare crisis, event, instant, edge (arête) which gives momentum to Prime Mover]
LOBL.linkedContent: [compare crisis, event, instant, edge (arête) which gives momentum to Prime Mover]

POR.content: via Aristotle, sight is privileged sense re: knowledge, knowing for sake of knowing linked to sight as senseless sensation (sight privileged even when no praxis in view)
POR.linkedContent: via Aristotle, sight is privileged sense re: knowledge, knowing for sake of knowing linked to sight as senseless sensation (sight privileged even when no praxis in view)

POR.content: acc. Aristotle, math developed in Egypt due to leisure time enjoyed by priestly caste
POR.linkedContent: acc. Aristotle, math developed in Egypt due to leisure time enjoyed by priestly caste

HERP.content: Heidegger enacts “destruction” on Aristotle’s broken analysis of logos as judgment, and has reservations about man as animal rationale, zōon logon echon
HERP.linkedContent: Heidegger enacts “destruction” on Aristotle’s broken analysis of logos as judgment, and has reservations about man as animal rationale, zōon logon echon

HERP.content: mishearing, essential possibility for Heidegger [error in Aristotle]
HERP.linkedContent: mishearing, essential possibility for Heidegger [error in Aristotle]

POOF.content: Aristotle privileges to love over being loved, active over passive (potential) > Derrida points to a tense btwn active/passive, the question of aimance (lovence) [see pp. 24-5n] ——Aristotle places same & other in figure of the other [the friend], cette étrange configuration donne à penser
POOF.linkedContent: Aristotle privileges to love over being loved, active over passive (potential) > Derrida points to a tense btwn active/passive, the question of aimance (lovence) [see pp. 24-5n] ——Aristotle places same & other in figure of the other [the friend], cette étrange configuration donne à penser

POOF.content: more worthwhile (vaut mieux) “to love,” preeminence of form over matter > Derrida will demonstrate how, for once, w/ Aristotle, death situated on side of form & act: act of friendship bears death in itself
POOF.linkedContent: more worthwhile (vaut mieux) “to love,” preeminence of form over matter > Derrida will demonstrate how, for once, w/ Aristotle, death situated on side of form & act: act of friendship bears death in itself

POOF.content: for Aristotle, friendship linked to knowledge, science & self-consciousness held (tenue) in pledge, alliance, promise, performative chain [of friendship]
POOF.linkedContent: for Aristotle, friendship linked to knowledge, science & self-consciousness held (tenue) in pledge, alliance, promise, performative chain [of friendship]

POOF.content: if Prime Mover [Lover?] sets himself in motion w/out moving or being moved, isn’t he analogically the beloved, the absolute desirable? on the side of death?
POOF.linkedContent: if Prime Mover [Lover?] sets himself in motion w/out moving or being moved, isn’t he analogically the beloved, the absolute desirable? on the side of death?

POOF.content: lover, subject, soul, life, breath, philetikoi [see p.12], necessary; beloved, philótimoi, object, accident, soulless, dead
POOF.linkedContent: lover, subject, soul, life, breath, philetikoi [see p.12], necessary; beloved, philótimoi, object, accident, soulless, dead

POOF.content: Aristotle’s 2 forms of justice: 1) numerical equality (kat’arithmón), brothers 2) proportional equality (kat’analogían), father-son [cf. Aristotle’s Politics]
POOF.linkedContent: Aristotle’s 2 forms of justice: 1) numerical equality (kat’arithmón), brothers 2) proportional equality (kat’analogían), father-son [cf. Aristotle’s Politics]

POOF.content: hard to follow Heidegger’s epochal scansion of philía, yes, anachronistic to find subject/object in Aristotle, but how can he say there's no anthropological or psychological vantage point?
POOF.linkedContent: hard to follow Heidegger’s epochal scansion of philía, yes, anachronistic to find subject/object in Aristotle, but how can he say there's no anthropological or psychological vantage point?

POOF.content: acc. Heidegger, Christianity is an education of passions, even a psychology, a psychological subjectivity—all post-Aristotelian friendships are Christian, same goes for ‘politics’
POOF.linkedContent: acc. Heidegger, Christianity is an education of passions, even a psychology, a psychological subjectivity—all post-Aristotelian friendships are Christian, same goes for ‘politics’

POOF.content: via Deguy, Aristotle overtook to ruin the capital letters of Platonism, the eídos of friendship, by calling the witness to the stand, an “actual” friend > Derrida will take sign of this ruin & no longer answer call to witness stand
POOF.linkedContent: via Deguy, Aristotle overtook to ruin the capital letters of Platonism, the eídos of friendship, by calling the witness to the stand, an “actual” friend > Derrida will take sign of this ruin & no longer answer call to witness stand

A.content: acc. Derrida in OS via Heidegger, Kant, Hegel inherited exoteric aporia from Aristotle, who acknowledges lack of clarity in saying “aporia is exoteric” w/out then deconstructing it
A.linkedContent: acc. Derrida in OS via Heidegger, Kant, Hegel inherited exoteric aporia from Aristotle, who acknowledges lack of clarity in saying “aporia is exoteric” w/out then deconstructing it

VM.content: Aristotle rigorously demonstrated that Being is neither genre nor principle (Metaphysics B, 3, 998 b 20)
VM.linkedContent: Aristotle rigorously demonstrated that Being is neither genre nor principle (Metaphysics B, 3, 998 b 20)

VM.content: doctrine of uniformity of Being (don Scotus, Heidegger) incompatible w/ Aristotelian-Thomist Being in which question of 1st/2nd [re: universal/singular] remains
VM.linkedContent: doctrine of uniformity of Being (don Scotus, Heidegger) incompatible w/ Aristotelian-Thomist Being in which question of 1st/2nd [re: universal/singular] remains

S.content: Aristotle’s dynamis (potentiality) is a virtuality oriented by a telos
S.linkedContent: Aristotle’s dynamis (potentiality) is a virtuality oriented by a telos

PPHS.content: in Peri Hermeneias [Aristotle spells out logo-phonocentrism]: spoken words (ta en tēi phōnēi) are symbols of mental experiences, written words are symbols of spoken words, mental experiences are the same for all
PPHS.linkedContent: in Peri Hermeneias [Aristotle spells out logo-phonocentrism]: spoken words (ta en tēi phōnēi) are symbols of mental experiences, written words are symbols of spoken words, mental experiences are the same for all

WM.content: Aristotle: just like in philosophy, an acute mind will find resemblances in things far apart
WM.linkedContent: Aristotle: just like in philosophy, an acute mind will find resemblances in things far apart

WM.content: imitation sets man apart from beasts, man alone takes pleasure in imitating > metaphor, an effect of mimēsis and homoiosis, manifestation of analogy, a subordinate means of knowledge: full truth preferred to metaphor
WM.linkedContent: imitation sets man apart from beasts, man alone takes pleasure in imitating > metaphor, an effect of mimēsis and homoiosis, manifestation of analogy, a subordinate means of knowledge: full truth preferred to metaphor

WM.content: Aristotle reproaches Plato for using “poetic metaphors” and hollow language when he said Ideas are the paradigms in which other things participate
WM.linkedContent: Aristotle reproaches Plato for using “poetic metaphors” and hollow language when he said Ideas are the paradigms in which other things participate

WM.content: to be learning something, recognizing resemblance (the same), is the greatest pleasure, this pleasure is the second [?] “cause” of mimēsis and metaphor
WM.linkedContent: to be learning something, recognizing resemblance (the same), is the greatest pleasure, this pleasure is the second [?] “cause” of mimēsis and metaphor

WM.content: mimeme (neither thing itself, nor tout autre) > elliptical syllogism of mimēsis provides as recompense a dividend of pleasure, “everything like & akin to oneself is pleasant”: finishing work, laughter of resemblance (also, we should not spend all our time imitating monstrous things)
WM.linkedContent: mimeme (neither thing itself, nor tout autre) > elliptical syllogism of mimēsis provides as recompense a dividend of pleasure, “everything like & akin to oneself is pleasant”: finishing work, laughter of resemblance (also, we should not spend all our time imitating monstrous things)

WM.content: for Aristotle, proper name is nonmetaphorical prime mover of metaphor, father of all figures > everything turns around it, towards it > metaphor as substitution of proper names w/ fixed meaning & referent
WM.linkedContent: for Aristotle, proper name is nonmetaphorical prime mover of metaphor, father of all figures > everything turns around it, towards it > metaphor as substitution of proper names w/ fixed meaning & referent

WM.content: via Aristotle, univocity (one meaning per noun) is telos (essence) of language, there is only finite polysemia: a nonmasterable dissemination (an irreducible polysemia) is not even a polysemia, it belongs to what is outside language, and thus outside humanity
WM.linkedContent: via Aristotle, univocity (one meaning per noun) is telos (essence) of language, there is only finite polysemia: a nonmasterable dissemination (an irreducible polysemia) is not even a polysemia, it belongs to what is outside language, and thus outside humanity

OS.content: time compared by Aristotle to movement and chance, w/out being either one of them, time can only occur en tēi psukhēi > time’s analogy: what is traced (le tracé) as line, grammē
OS.linkedContent: time compared by Aristotle to movement and chance, w/out being either one of them, time can only occur en tēi psukhēi > time’s analogy: what is traced (le tracé) as line, grammē

OS.content: if Aristotle conceived time in a way not dominated by presence, did Heidegger arrest this possibility in Sein und Zeit, did Kant just make explicit the evaded question [section title] in Physics IV? such making explicit keeps to (se tient) the system de l’éludé
OS.linkedContent: if Aristotle conceived time in a way not dominated by presence, did Heidegger arrest this possibility in Sein und Zeit, did Kant just make explicit the evaded question [section title] in Physics IV? such making explicit keeps to (se tient) the system de l’éludé

OS.content: Aristotle repeats aporia of Zeno’s argument re: time, says it clarifies nothing, but does not deconstruct it > time’s nonbeing pre-comprehended as nonpresence in relation to determination of being as present
OS.linkedContent: Aristotle repeats aporia of Zeno’s argument re: time, says it clarifies nothing, but does not deconstruct it > time’s nonbeing pre-comprehended as nonpresence in relation to determination of being as present

OS.content: transition from parousia to absolute subjectivity does not disrupt Aristotelianism: prime mover, presence, desire, eros, “desire is desire of presence,” absolute subjectivity, circle, return to self, parousia as self-presence > prime mover, noēsis noēseōs, as subject
OS.linkedContent: transition from parousia to absolute subjectivity does not disrupt Aristotelianism: prime mover, presence, desire, eros, “desire is desire of presence,” absolute subjectivity, circle, return to self, parousia as self-presence > prime mover, noēsis noēseōs, as subject

OS.content: for Aristotle, potentiality & act are not symmetrical: governed by teleology of presence, act (energeia) as presence (ousia, parousia)
OS.linkedContent: for Aristotle, potentiality & act are not symmetrical: governed by teleology of presence, act (energeia) as presence (ousia, parousia)

OS.content: for Aristotle, being-together [of nun and stigmē] not a determination of Being but very production of Being > ama as the pivot (cheville) (clavis), the key opening & closing metaphysics > this complicity so self-effacing as to barely be noticed, the common origin of space & time > Aristotle says w/out saying [Rousseau describing w/out declaring]: the dyad as the minimum
OS.linkedContent: for Aristotle, being-together [of nun and stigmē] not a determination of Being but very production of Being > ama as the pivot (cheville) (clavis), the key opening & closing metaphysics > this complicity so self-effacing as to barely be noticed, the common origin of space & time > Aristotle says w/out saying [Rousseau describing w/out declaring]: the dyad as the minimum

ROP.content: Giusti: for Aristotle, art of dialectic is the exercise of dialogue w/ tradition [?]
ROP.linkedContent: Giusti: for Aristotle, art of dialectic is the exercise of dialogue w/ tradition [?]

ATIA.content: the abyss of autos, ipseity, autokinesis: we must surrender (get) to the heart of the abyss btwn law of nature (reaction) & law of freedom (response & responsibility)
ATIA.linkedContent: the abyss of autos, ipseity, autokinesis: we must surrender (get) to the heart of the abyss btwn law of nature (reaction) & law of freedom (response & responsibility)

ATIA.content: Aristotle, a fundamental reference for ATIA [or “this seminar”]
ATIA.linkedContent: Aristotle, a fundamental reference for ATIA [or “this seminar”]

ATIA.content: re: animal, Heidegger continues Aristotle’s tradition of steresis (privation)
ATIA.linkedContent: re: animal, Heidegger continues Aristotle’s tradition of steresis (privation)

ATIA.content: Aristotle’s non-apophantic logos (neither enunciative nor declarative): euchē, prayer, entreaty, requesting; for Derrida, these would open breach in whole apparatus [of “as such”?]
ATIA.linkedContent: Aristotle’s non-apophantic logos (neither enunciative nor declarative): euchē, prayer, entreaty, requesting; for Derrida, these would open breach in whole apparatus [of “as such”?]

FS.content: Aristotle’s concept of movement: transition to the act, which is itself repose of the desired form
FS.linkedContent: Aristotle’s concept of movement: transition to the act, which is itself repose of the desired form

RM.content: Aristotle’s 4 types of metaphor (Poetics): 1) apo genous epi eidos, ex. “here stands my ship” 4) kata to analogon
RM.linkedContent: Aristotle’s 4 types of metaphor (Poetics): 1) apo genous epi eidos, ex. “here stands my ship” 4) kata to analogon

AFR.content: Condillac denounces Aristotle’s philosophy as unconscious empiricism: Aristotle takes derived generalities as premises, products for seeds or origins (germes)
AFR.linkedContent: Condillac denounces Aristotle’s philosophy as unconscious empiricism: Aristotle takes derived generalities as premises, products for seeds or origins (germes)

AFR.content: Condillac: the science Aristotle called ζητουμéνη (desired, sought after) is the general knowledge of soul on which all sciences depend (what science of happiness is to the arts), this science opens future, providence—so wise man is not stuck in present
AFR.linkedContent: Condillac: the science Aristotle called ζητουμéνη (desired, sought after) is the general knowledge of soul on which all sciences depend (what science of happiness is to the arts), this science opens future, providence—so wise man is not stuck in present

TN.content: Aristotle (Peri psuchēs): 1) touch is “inward,” internal 2) flesh is the “medium” 3) touch has for its object tangible & intangible (tou haptou kai anaptou) [a touchable un-touchable?]
TN.linkedContent: Aristotle (Peri psuchēs): 1) touch is “inward,” internal 2) flesh is the “medium” 3) touch has for its object tangible & intangible (tou haptou kai anaptou) [a touchable un-touchable?]

TN.content: Aristotle’s Peri psuchēs (de Anima) is treatise on the pure life of the living
TN.linkedContent: Aristotle’s Peri psuchēs (de Anima) is treatise on the pure life of the living

TN.content: acc. Aristotle, touch: co-extensive w/ animal life, the genus of senses
TN.linkedContent: acc. Aristotle, touch: co-extensive w/ animal life, the genus of senses

BSi.content: Hobbes’ sovereignty breaks w/ Aristotle’s political animal [?]
for Aristotle, kurios (sovereign), structural difference btwn state & family (latter comes first [historically]) > go to the arkhē to develop best view of things
BSi.linkedContent: for Aristotle, kurios (sovereign), structural difference btwn state & family (latter comes first [historically]) > go to the arkhē to develop best view of things

BSi.content: Aristotle: those who foresee w/ mind naturally master, those who foresee w/ body naturally slave—both same interest [?]
BSi.linkedContent: Aristotle: those who foresee w/ mind naturally master, those who foresee w/ body naturally slave—both same interest [?]

BSi.content: Aristotle: only under ruler are slaves and women distinguished; ox is poor man’s slave
BSi.linkedContent: Aristotle: only under ruler are slaves and women distinguished; ox is poor man’s slave

BSi.content: Aristotle: autarkeia (self-sufficiency), sovereign, has an end in himself, is best—self-sufficiency the end of everything
BSi.linkedContent: Aristotle: autarkeia (self-sufficiency), sovereign, has an end in himself, is best—self-sufficiency the end of everything

BSi.content: city is natural reality, man destined to live in city (Aristotle links politics & logos)
BSi.linkedContent: city is natural reality, man destined to live in city (Aristotle links politics & logos)

BSi.content: phonē (which animals also have) does not suffice to define logos

OG.content: Aristotle’s phono-logocentrism: voice, spoken symbols, immediately proximate to the universal language of mental experience (pathēmata tes psychēs), closest to the thing, the signified
OG.linkedContent: Aristotle’s phono-logocentrism: voice, spoken symbols, immediately proximate to the universal language of mental experience (pathēmata tes psychēs), closest to the thing, the signified

OG.content: reason can’t think (and thus constituted by) this double infringement: there’s a lack in Nature and because of that very fact something is added to it, the supplement as image & representation of nature, image neither in nor out [Aristotle’s “neither for nor against”]
OG.linkedContent: reason can’t think (and thus constituted by) this double infringement: there’s a lack in Nature and because of that very fact something is added to it, the supplement as image & representation of nature, image neither in nor out [Aristotle’s “neither for nor against”]
